Spike fiddle of northern Afghanistan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan; resonator may be spherical like the kamanche or made from a square tin can
Single-string spike fiddle of the Maghreb; resembles the goge
Single-string spike fiddle of Bénin
Single-string spike fiddle with gourd resonator from Western Africa, term used by Hausa and Yoruba people in ia Nigeria and Niger
[gonje] Single-string spike fiddle of the Dagbamba people of Ghana
Ancient three-string fiddle of Russia and Belarussia with a pear-shaped body
Single-string fiddle of Yugoslavia, often with horse-head decoration on top of neck
Corn stalk fiddle of Bosnia and Serbia
Two-stringed spike fiddle from Korea with wooden soundboard

Norwegian folk fiddle, resembling the violin, with 4 melody strings and 4 sympathetic strings; often elaborately decorated with geometrical and vegetal designs, with the head of a Norwegian lion or dragon on the pegbox
Two-stringed spike fiddle from China, with a resonator made from gourd; the pegbox of the one from MIM Phoenix has a 'fantasy' wooden design
Fiddle from Myanmar; shaped like a violin, often a highly decorated pegbox; has become obsolete now
Ancient Chinese lute; NB in Metropolitan Museum this is described as a fiddle as it comes with a bow!
Generic term for Chinese fiddle, literally 'barbarian string instrument'
Fiddle of the Uyghur people (mainly from the Xinjiang Uyghur autonomous region in western China); highly decorated and often with a bird (nightingale) on the pegbox
Three-stringed fiddle from the Wends or Sorbs of eastern Germany and Slavonic countries; soundboard is waisted, the instrument looks like a primitive violin
Single-string tube fiddle of Burundi with a soundbox made of cow horn
Two-stringed fiddle of the Tuva people of Siberia, often with horse head on pegbox
Turkish fiddle, originally a gourd spike-fiddle (type of kabak = 'gourd fiddle')
Single-string spike fiddle of the Touareg in northern Africa, with a calabash resonator and often two soundholes in the membrane
Harp-lute from the Gogo people in Tanzania, consisting of up to 14 metal strings running over an oblique bridge. The resonator is made of a calebash
Two-string fiddle of the Han Chinese, especially from the north; smaller than erhu
Four-string spike fiddle of Iraq; 'joza' means coconut, and refers to the coconut resonator
Anthropomorphic fiddle of the Holo and Suku people of southwestern DR Congo and northern Angola; the head is the pegbox; the soundboard is a thin wooden board
One-stringed tube fiddle of the Chewa people in southern and central Malawi; the projecting tip of the neck acts as string-holder; Werner notes the term chimwenyuwenyu on Likoma island in Lake Malawi
Three-stringed fiddle of the Lunda and Chokwe people of southern DR Congo, northeastern Angola and northern Zambia
Short-necked fiddle with large round soundboard from Rajasthan, played by the Manghaniyar caste
Fiddle from Armenia, with rectangular soundboard and 3 or 4 strings
Spike fiddle of Iran with a spherical body often inlaid with mother-of-pearl or bone; formerly three strings, modern instruments have four
(i) Short-necked fiddle from Turkey with a bottle-shaped soundboard and three strings; (ii) in Western Turkey the kemençe is similar to the Greek lyra with a pear shaped soundboard and three strings
The kemençe with a bottle-shaped soundboard played by Greek refugees from the Turkish Black Sea coast; also called Pontic lyra
Mongolian two-stringed spike tube fiddle, mostly used in ensembles
Single-string half spike fiddle from the Daza and Teda of Tibesti and Ouaddai in Chad

Three-string fiddle of Madhya Pradesh in India with a wooden soundbox; however, the kikirs in the FF database in M+ all have one string and a soundbox made from ceramic material (see description TUA-326); on the internet (see sources), the kingri is also said to have a resonator box made from unglazed pottery (New Grove)
Apache fiddle made from a hollowed-out agave stalk, with two or three strings; often decorated with geometrical or natural designs; also called tsi edo atl
Fiddle from Japan, derived from the Chinese huqin
Japanese indigenous spike box fiddle, usually with three strings (but sometimes the highest string is doubled)
Gulmantché term for the one-stringed spike fiddle in Burkina Faso
Three-stringed spike fiddle of Okinawa, Japan. The resonator is half a coconut shell, covered with snake skin
Single-string spike fiddle of the Hausa in Nigeria, smaller than goge
Single-string spike fiddle of the Susu people in Guinea and Sierra Leone
Single-string fiddle of the southern Philippines
Single-string fiddle from Albania, similar to the Gusle; in New Grove spelled as Lahutë
Short-necked fiddle from Greece, with a pear-shaped body and two D-shaped soundholes in the soundboard; usually three strings
Three-string fiddle of the Ilonggot people of the northern Philippines
Generic term for several instruments in Madagascar; here it refers to fiddles from Madagascar
Two-stringed tube fiddle from Guangxi and Ghuizhou provinces in China; the name means 'horse bone fiddle', the resonator is made of horse bone
[sekhankula] Single-string fiddle from southern Africa, mainly among Sotho people; it has a tin can resonator
Single-stringed spike fiddle from Ethiopia with a rhombus shaped resonator

Small fiddle of the Wielkopolska (Greater Poland), region of Poland. An instrument with medieval roots; before World War I used in Poland during the ritual part of the wedding (wedding feast) together with the wedding bagpipe (Koziol weselny / Koziol bialy); after World War II reactivated in the S. Moniuszko Music School in Zbaszyn; now used in the folk revival, too. Almost entirely carved from one piece of wood; three strings; one of bridge’s feet longer, going through an opening in the top plate and resting on the back plate, functioning as a soundpost
Single-string fiddle of the Kamba/Mijikenda people of Kenya
Single-string fiddle of the Guaycuru people in Chaco, Argentina
Fiddle (khuur) with horse head from Mongolia; two strings and trapezoid soundbox
One-stringed tube fiddle from Nyanja people in Mozambique; string is tuned with tuning loop around neck
Spike fiddle from northern Sumatra from the Batak people
Ox horn fiddle from the Buyi people in southern China, the resonator being of ox horn and the neck of wood
''Ox leg" two-stringed fiddle of the Dong people in Guizhou, south-western China (shape is that of an ox leg, hence the name)
Single-string fiddle (of the Songhay people?) of Mali; noteable performer Ali Farka Touré
Peul term for the one-stringed spike fiddle in Western Africa; note the soundhole in the soundbox, not in the soundboard
Keyed fiddle from Scandinavia and northern Germany, with melody strings, bourdon strings and sympathetic strings; it plays an important role in Swedish folk music
Single-string spike fiddle of the Luo people of Kenya
Single-string spike fiddle from Manipur, north-eastern India without tuning peg (string is directly attached to the neck); it comes with a large iron bow with bells on it
Spike tube fiddle from Tibet/Bhutan, with a resonator made of wood, metal or ivory; it has two to four strings
Single-string fiddle of the Pulluvan in Kerala, south India. The neck is glued to the soundbox and starts like a crescent which continues into a neck and ends in the pegbox
Long fiddle from Lithuania, with a bladder as resonator, over which run the strings; it is played vertically, standing on the ground
Two-stringed fiddle of the Karakalpak, Kazakh and Kirghiz people of Central Asia; resonator is a deeply carved out ladle, the bottom half is covered with skin
A term for various chordophones, both fiddles and lutes; within the Formalized Fiddle it may refer to the Javanese rabab, the Arabic box spike fiddle, and the north African rabab
Spike fiddle from the Arab world; may refer to both the spike bowl fiddle and the quadrangular spike fiddle
Portugese fiddle resembling the western violin, used in Brazil during feasts

Spike fiddle from Rajasthan and Gujarat, north-west India; the resonator consists of half a coconut shell; there are simple forms with only two strings, and more complex ones which have sympathetic strings as well and are decorated with tassles and fabric, the bow may be decorated with bells
[kora, sasong, rebang] Single-string spike fiddle of Flores in Indonesia; the resonator is half a coconut shell, covered with a sago palm-leaf sheath
Wolof term for the single-string fiddle with gourd resonator from Senegambia; soundhole in soundbox, not in soundboard

[sason, mbeka, sato] Single-string spike fiddle from Flores, Indonesia. The resonator is half a coconut shell, covered with a leaf; a flat wooden stick is inserted through the resonator and serves as a neck and peg
One-string spike fiddle with gourd resonator of the Moosé in Burkina Faso; noteable performer Nouss Nabil

Hindustani classical sarangi: short-necked fiddle, soundbox is made from one piece of wood, covered with skin; membrane is waisted; it has three playing strings and (many) sympathetic strings. Nepali sarangi: small short-necked fiddle made from one piece of wood; the lower part of the soundbox is covered with skin, the upper part is open; it typically has 4 strings; not to be confused with sarinda (see below)
Short-necked bowl fiddle from South Asia; resonator is rounded and deeply waisted, the lower part is covered with skin, while the upper part is open and has the shape of an umbrella
One-string fiddle with tin can resonator at the top end of the Tswana and Xhoisan people from Botswana
Four-string fiddle of the Han Chinese (si = four)
Two-stringed spike tube fiddle of Thailand, resembling the Chinese erhu
Two-string fiddle of Laos, with a jackwood or bamboo soundbox
Three-stringed spike fiddle of Thailand, resembling the Javanese rebab; resonator is coconut shell with three bulges on the back, covered with skin
Two-string fiddle of Thailand, with a coconut resonator with a carved out back and skin soundtable
Single-string fiddle of the Berbers of southern Morocco, with a round soundbox covered with skin; the peg is inserted laterally and the string runs in an angle over the soundboard
Single-string fiddle from Latvia, with a bladder resonator; it is played vertically

Small polish fiddle. Suka is known thanks to an item from the Bilgoraj area, Poland, shown at the First Polish Music Exhibition in Warsaw in 1888 (written accound by Jan Karlowicz, sketch by Tadeusz Dowgird, 1888, watercolour painting by Wojciech Gerson, 1896); in the second half of the 19th c., and possibly at the beginning of the 20th c. it was used in the south of the Lublin region (Bilgoraj area), probably accompanied by a single-skin drum; now used by artists of the folk revival; suka is played in the vertical position (hung over the shoulder on a string or leaned on the knee); players applied side string shortening (so-called fingernail technique)
Single-string tube fiddle of the Hima in Rwanda and northeastern DR Congo
Fiddle used by the Sundanese and Badui people in West Java, with a trapezoidal resonator. Often has a carved-out pegbox
Newly developed spike fiddle, created by Peter Biffin; there are several types; the instrument resembles a kamanche
Urdu name for the long-necked fretted peacock fiddle in India and Pakistan; in northern India it is known as mayuri
Three-stringed box fiddle of the Inuit people
Single-string spike fiddle of the Baggara people of Sudan
Spike tube fiddle of the Kikuyu people in Kenya
Two-string fiddle of the Han Chinese; resonator is coconut, covered with wooden soundboard; bridge is usually a sea-shell; resembles banhu but pegs are dorsally inserted
General term for fiddle in Central and Eastern Africa
Two-string Chinese fiddle; a 'middle' erhu with an alto range
Small fiddle from the Tatra mountains in Poland
Harp-lute from the Bwa and Gouin people in Burkina Faso
Harp-lute from Burkina Faso. Seven or eight strings. The resonator is a half or three quarter calebash
Harp-lute from the Turka people from Burkina Faso. Often with a metal buzzer at the end of the neck

Synonymes: Cai dan nha tro;Dan nha tro

Définition: Two-stringed plucked spike lute with a loose cylindrical bridge (piece of bambou stem) from the Hausa people in Burkina Faso. It has a half-calabash soundbox
Wooden griot lute from the Fulbé people of Burkina Faso

Monochord calabash half-spike lute of the Fulbe people in Burkina Faso, more specifically of the riimaaybe, "descendants of the captives", belonging to a specific stratos of fulbe society, "dispossessed of their cultural origins after having been cpatured during wars or raids, or purchased from neighbouring posers by the Fulbe... the descendants of the captiveswork the land in direct usufruct. The musical practices of the different social groups remain clearly differentiatedThe riimaaybe musicians are more or less seasonal speciaists, they only play for their own festivities, well distinct from those of the Fulbe" Sandrine Loncke, Burkina Faso. The voice of the Fulbe / La voix des Peuls, CD Le Chant du monde CNR 274 1079, 1997, CD notes, p. 25-26, 35-36
Two-stringed calabash lute from the Bissa people in Burkina Faso
Wooden lute from the Moosè people in Burkina Faso
Wooden griot lute from the Fulbé people of Burkina Faso

Five-string plucked lute of the Kongo-Bembe peoples of the Republic of the Congo. The 5 metal strings are tuned with large upright tuning pegs fitted with metal jingles. The strings are plucked with the thumb and forefinger of both hands. The instrument is used mainly to accompany singing
Lute from the Teke People in the Republic of Congo. Used to accompany ritual and popular dances
Gulmancé term for the Griot lute in Burkina Faso
Tamasheq term for the griot lute in Burkina Faso
Bowl lyre of the Luo people from Kenya
Large bowl lyre of the Gusii people in Kenya, with large flat bridge
Musical bow of the Bissa people of Burkina Faso. It has a metal string and a resonator made of a calabash cut in two. The top part of the calabas may be attached to the upper part of the bow
Musical bow from the Samo peopàle in Burkina Faso consisting of a string supported by a flexible wooden string bearer.  A calebash is attached as resonator
Bow lute (5 bows) of the Kongo-Bembe people of the Republic of Congo

Bow lute of the Teke people in Central Africa, the Congo's and Gabon. Five fibre strings are mounted almost perpendicular to a large sound box, on which geometrical decorations are engraved and burned. A buzzing effect is produced by metal jingles on the string-bearers

Synonymes: Cai dan thap luc;Dan thap luc

Définition: Triangual frame zither from the Lobi people of Burkina Faso, with several gourds attached as resonator, including one at the point of V of the arm. Six to nine strings. May have a metal buzzer at the end of the arm
Stick zither with a notched bridge, which supports its five strings in a plane at right angles to that of the string-bearer. Unique to the area of western central Africa
Stick zither with one resonator and 5 strings from the Lobi people in Burkina Faso
Rectangual raft zither made of  straw stems bound together and with the strings cut out from the stems. From  the Bwa and Samo  people in Burkina Faso

Pedal accordion, bellows connected to the instrument with a two-piece pipe. After World War I the accordion became a popular component of polish folk bands (together with the violin and the drum); the pedal type being especially popular in Mazovia on the right side of the Vistula river (the region of Kurpie and the area of Garwolin), to some degree also in Podlasie (Podlachia)
Cornemuse du Val d'Aran, sans bourdon et à anche simple
Basic component of traditional folk bands in the south of the Beskid Zywiecki region, Poland
Cornemuse de Galice

A polish bagpipe from Podhale region. A mouth blown instrument; four voices; has a short triple chanter-drone pipe (5+1 fingerholes) and a long drone pipe ending in a hyperbolic bell (of a clarinet type); all pipes with cylindrical bores; bag made from a goat's whole skin; formerly played solo (by shepherds, wandering musicians), nowadays in folk revival, sometimes included in Podhale bands. The ability to build and play the Podhale bagpipe, or goat, were included on the National List of Intangible Cultural Heritage

A polish bagpipe with low tuning and elegiac sound; formerly used during the ritual part of the wedding ceremony together with mazanki, after World War II reactivated in the S. Moniuszko Music School in Zbaszyn and in the folk revival

A bagpipe with 16th c. roots; the biggest of Polish bagpipes with the lowest tuning and an elegiac sound; traditional element of folk bands in west Greater Poland (along with violins and, after World War I, an E-flat clarinet)
Cornemuse roussillonnaise

Idioglot transverse clarinet of the Bissa people in Burkina Faso. Made from a hollowed-out millet stalk. It has two small gourd resonators with side windows placed over the ends of the stalk. It usually has a finger-hole at the distal end which may be stopped by the left thumb. http://inconstantsol.blogspot.be/2014/01/musique-bisa-de-haute-volta-rec-1961.html

Idioglot transverse clarinet from the Nuni people in Burkina Faso. Made from a hollowed-out millet stalk. To be compared with the Bumpan of the Bissa people in Burkina Faso, but without the  small gourd resonators over the ends of the stalk
Clarinette indonésienne

Note d'application: "Antara" is the Quecha word for the Andean single-rowed panpipe

Définition: Flûte oblique d'Arménie, d'origine pastorale et semblable au blur turc

Wooden transverse flute from the Fulbe people in Burkina Fasothe Fulbe people in Burkina Faso, more specifically of the riimaaybe, "descendants of the captives", belonging to a specific stratos of fulbe society, "dispossessed of their cultural origins after having been cpatured during wars or raids, or purchased from neighbouring posers by the Fulbe... the descendants of the captiveswork the land in direct usufruct. The musical practices of the different social groups remain clearly differentiated. The riimaaybe musicians are more or less seasonal speciaists, they only play for their own festivities, well distinct from those of the Fulbe"
"Flute of the conqueror"; end blown sculptured  flute from the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Flûte originaire du Laos et du Vietnam, similaire au bawu
Term for a North-African bamboo duct flute
Note d'application: Djaouak is also an alternative term (synonyms) for Juwak

Définition: A North African term for an oblique rim-blown flute

Bambou transverse flute from the Fulbe people in Burkina Faso (made from a millet stalk), about 40 to 50 cm in length. These days, musicians prefer to have tube of forged iron, which does not go out of tune, and hardly wears out. The instrument is played obliquely so as to compensate for the absence of a prepared embouchure. the flute has 3 to 4 playing holes; the flautist can however obtain intermediate tones by fractional fingering
Small end-blown wooden flute (15 to 20 cm) from the Bissa people in Burkina Faso
Wooden sculpted flute (30 to 40 cm) with two fingerholes used to accompany the masked dances of the Nuni people from Burkina Faso
North African term for an oblique rim-blown flute.
Wooden sculpted flute (ca. 25 cm) with two fingerholes from the Nuni people from Burkina Faso
Flûte oblique égyptienne en bambou à 3 sections et 6 trous de jeu
Small wooden sculpted flute (12 to 15 cm) with fingerholes, in the form of a stylised bird, from the Nuni people of Burkina Faso

Note d'application: '"Mimby is a generic term for "flute" in Guarani language. "Mimby" can be side-blown, notched or internal duct flute', Edgardo Civallero, mail to Norman Rodger and Saskia Willaert, 5 October 2016

Définition: Small wooden sculpted flute with fingerholes, in the form of a stylised bird, from the Nuni people of Burkina Faso
Flûte oblique de Sumatra

Note d'application: "Siku" is the Aymara word for the Andean double-rowed panpipe. "Zampoña" is the Spanish word for it

Définition: Side-blown flute from the Peul people in Senegal. Named after the cane's name out of which it is made. Mouthpiece made of wax. Often covered in colourful textile
Argyle ocarina from the Yana people in Burkina Faso
Wooden flute from the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Wooden flute from the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Small wooden sculptured flute, often in the form of a stylized bird, with fingerholes, and open at the end. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Small wooden scultpured flute, often in the form of a stylized bird, with fingerholes, and open at the end. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Small wooden sculptured flute, often in the form of a stylized bird, with fingerholes, and open at the end. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Small wooden sculptured flute, often in the form of a stylized bird, with fingerholes, and closed at the end. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Whistle, end-blown, stopped at the end and with no fingerholes. Whistle. Often decoartedwith loose hanging strips
Wooden sculptured flute, closed at the end and with fingerholes. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso
Transverse flute from the Gulmancé people in the est of Burkina Faso. Tube in bambou or plastic; often covered with leather. Four fingerholes
Wooden whistle open at the end and with fingerholes. From the Kô people in Burkina Faso

Note d'application: "Zampoña" is the Spanish word for the Andean double-rowed panpipe. "Siku" is the Aymara word for it

Définition: Small side-blown wooden horn of the Moosé and Nuni people, Burkina. The mouthpiece is cut in the outer curve of the horn

A kind of horn (conical profile), made from a branch that is cut along in two halves, then each is hollowed, and finally both are put back together with the help of pitch and metal hoops; formerly used as a signal instrument (mainly in herding); since 19th c. used during Advent and watchnight service on Christmas Eve (mainly in north-east and east regions of Poland); nowadays as part of folk revival
Side blown horn of the Bomitaba people in the Likouala region of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antilope horn
Side blown horn of the Teke people in the Plateaux region of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. Protects against lightning and serves as a means of communication
Side blown horn of the Kongo and Bembe people of the Bouenza region in the south of Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. "Mvouri" = "antilope". Used to accompany songs calling for rain
Side blown antelope horn of the Mbosi and Kongo people of the Congo's.
Animal horn with mouthpiece cut out on the outer curved side of the horn, with an additional whole which serves as a fingerhole. From the Nuni people in Burkina Faso

Small side blown horn of the Teke people in Gabon and the  Republic of the Congo. Made from an antelope horn. Serves as a means of communication and to call the spirits of the ancestors. "Ntsiemi" means "horn" in the Teke language

Note d'application: "Pututu" is a general term in Quechua and Aymara for "horn". Can also be a conchshell trumpet

Définition: Orgue à bouche du peuple Hmong
Hautbois du Couserans, France
Hautbois cylindrique à anche double idioglotte, présent en Chine
Hautbois du Bigorre, France
Hautbois arménien, l'anche double est appelée « gamish »
Hautbois sri lankais
Hautbois cylindrique turc
Hautbois droit ou courbe du Népal
Hautbois du Cambodge

A seasonal, polish folk instrument, made in the spring; would become porous and unplayable when it dried out; formerly a signal instrument (used by shepherds), often played by children, nowadays sometimes made as a music toy; body made from a spirally rolled piece of willow bark, fastened with a thorn ("przetyczka"); it should have a double reed ("bekas"), also made of willow bark, in the inlet
Hautbois cylindrique de la province de Sind (Pakistan)
Hautbois des Balkans
Hautbois de Catalogne
Hautbois de Catalogne

A kind of trumpet (straight labrosone) with a conical profile, made from a trunk of a young tree that is cut along in two halves, then each is hollowed, and finally both are put back together with the help of pitch; formerly used for apotropaic purposes (while making the ritual uproar) and signalling (shepherds, fishermen, firefighters, to signal the beginning of rituals and ceremonies); nowadays as part of folk revival; a symbol of Cassubians' ethnic identity (Kaszuby, the region of Poland)

Synonymes: Dngul dung;Dung chen;Dung dmar;Dungchen;Rag dug;Rag dung;Rag-dung;Ran dung;Rang-dung;Tongqin;Zangs dung

Définition: Large side blown anthopomorphic wooden natural trumpet of the Kongo-Bembe people of Republic of the Congo
